title: How to meet a Norwegian man - Quora

response.answer_text: Initially it is very easy. Alcohol is expensive here so when people go out to party they drink alcohol first at home, and shots at when they arrive. The alcohol sheds the skin of a morose Norwegian and they will easily talk to strangers. Also, they will probably wear their “beergoggles” which means you will look pretty darn good. But as cinderella lost her shoe at 12 o clock and turned back into a servant, so is the effects of alcohol. The handsome Norwegian man you went to bed with might wake up with a beer belly and bad breath. Also, the beergoggles are off and you might be meeting him for “the first time” hung over and with no makeup. Even if you pass the broken beer goggle test, the talkative prince has probably put his Norwegian stoic and silent coat on. So you can easily meet a Norwegian man at a pub, but it is safer to meet him casually at a coffee shop or hiking. Tip for a coffe shop: Try smiling and then looking away (no looking at him for more then a few seconds, that is unnerving to Norwegians and they think you might be a whore or a serial killer. Or both.). If he finds you attractive he will behave awkwardly by dropping his wallet and making ahem sounds. This is a window when you can smile again and take a open look at his wedding finger. If the courtship is well received the man will then awkrdly go out the door, regret it and come back and order another coffee- Then he will realise that you might think coffee number 2 is for a girlfriend and he will behave even more awkvard by saying “ I love coffee, must have two, just for me, I am single” Woila!

You could try Norway. It’s full of them. Online forums are good places as well — you just met me, and I’m a Norwegian man*. Problem solved! But seriously, you’re looking for a Norwegian man to date or marry, I think. That’s not at all impossible, though you might need to adjust your expectations a bit. Norwegians tend to have a more relaxed attitude towards sex, relationships, and marriage. The idea of “courtship” feels archaic for most Norwegians, so if yours is a very traditional culture you’re in for a big culture shock. That’s not to say Norwegians reject monogamy or commitment. Not at all. It’s just that that’s not the express goal of either sex or romantic relationships. It’s one possible and good outcome, but there’s nothing wrong with sex for sex’s sake or short-lived romantic entanglements. “Dating”, on the other hand, is a recent import that still feels awkward and stilted; most of the time, romantic relationships develop organically in the context of friendships or shared activities, like work or the local skiing club. Norwegians have clubs — klubber and foreninger — for everything. If you intend to meet a Norwegian man in Norway, join as many as you can. Meet guys by doing stuff together. The notion of sitting down for a formal dinner with the express purpose of evaluating each other for a romantic partnership, which is what a date is, just feels weird. If you need to rely on meeting Norwegians abroad, you should be targeting common vacation spots and the time frame late June through July. Spain is a popular destination — the Canary Islands, Ibiza, and Mallorca — as are the Greek islands of Rhodes and Crete. More Norwegians are choosing the Adriatic coast of Croatia, and Thailand is also popular, Phuket in particular. Look for the drunk, sunburnt Europeans with the sing-song language (though you may find it hard to distinguish between Norwegians and Swedes this way, Swedish guys are perfectly fine, too.) Be aware, though, of the beer-goggle phenomenon, as Elin Bentsen points out. A Norwegian man on vacation is even more likely than a Norwegian man at home to be drunk and on the lookout for nothing more than a vacation fling. Just because he’s happy to go to bed with you today does not mean he’s committed to marrying you. Far from it, in fact. Proceed with your eyes open, and good luck. * Taken. Sorry.
